messages.subject: Exploring CRM Solutions for FedEx Ops
messages.text: Hi David, I came across your recent interview in Supply Chain Tech Weekly — sounds like you're tackling some ambitious transformation goals. I'd love to learn more about how your team currently

messages.text: Hi Bruce, Appreciate the note. We are indeed evaluating a few platforms as part of a broader overhaul. That said, we're still early — mostly internal discussions and mapping out requirements. I

messages.text: Thanks, David — early is often the best time to get involved. Yes, we've worked with distributed teams in logistics and supply chain — UPS, DHL, and others. I'd be happy to tailor the

messages.text: Tuesday 11 am works. Please send the invite. In the meantime, feel free to share any material that outlines how your CRM handles multiple business units. That's been a sticking point for us with

messages.subject: Re: Exploring CRM Solutions for FedEx Ops
messages.text: Calendar invite sent! Attaching a 1-pager that highlights how we segment permissions, reporting, and workflows across business units — particularly helpful for teams like yours that manage both B2B and

messages.subject: Re: Exploring CRM Solutions for FedEx Ops
messages.text: Thanks Bruce — got the doc. Some good points in there. Let's cover ease of integration on the Slack. That's another area where we've hit snags in the past. Looking forward to learning more.

summary: This email thread between Bruce Wayne (sales rep) and David Gonzalez (FedEx prospect) outlines the initial discussions for CRM solutions. David expressed interest but raised concerns about the early stage of their evaluation, challenges with handling multiple business units, and integration difficulties. The conversation resulted in a scheduled meeting for Tuesday at 11 am, with Bruce providing a relevant document addressing the multi-business unit concern.
